greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Lexicographically earliest infinite sequence such that a(i) = a(j) => A329697(i) = A329697(j) and A336158(i) = A336158(j), for all i, j >= 1.
comment: Restricted growth sequence transform of the ordered pair [A329697(n), A336158(n)].

This sequence has an ability to see where the terms of A003401 are, as they are the indices of zeros in A336469. Specifically, they are numbers k that satisfy the condition A329697(k) = A001221(A336158(k)), i.e., numbers for which A329697(k) is equal to the number of distinct prime divisors of the odd part of k. See also comments in array A334100.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..65537
program: rgs_transform(invec) = { my(om = Map(), outvec = vector(length(invec)), u=1); for(i=1, length(invec), if(mapisdefined(om,invec[i]), my(pp = mapget(om, invec[i])); outvec[i] = outvec[pp] , mapput(om,invec[i],i); outvec[i] = u; u++ )); outvec; };
A046523(n) = { my(f=vecsort(factor(n)[, 2], , 4), p); prod(i=1, #f, (p=nextprime(p+1))^f[i]); };  \\ From A046523
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Jul 22 2020
